由于制片厂拒绝了工会提出的与流媒体电视订户数量挂钩的奖金要求，好莱坞明星们周四誓言将坚定不移地争取更高的薪酬和其他收益。

华特迪士尼(DIS.N) 、Netflix (NFLX.O)和其他媒体公司的谈判代表周三晚间表示，在审查了美国演员工会 (SAG-AFTRA) 演员工会的最新提议后，他们将暂停谈判。此举让与电影和电视编剧达成协议后迅速解决问题的希望破灭。

周四，演员们在纠察线上表示，他们对谈判破裂感到失望，但将继续推动加薪、人工智能保护和其他工作场所改善。

美国演员工会和美国电视交易协会 (SAG-AFTRA) 谈判委员会成员贾森·乔治 (Jason George) 在 Netflix 外表示：“电影中，英雄被击倒，你以为他们已经出局了。” “这就是你加倍努力并最终赢得胜利的部分。”

代表 16 万名演员和其他媒体专业人士的 SAG-AFTRA 成员自 7 月以来一直对电影和电视工作室进行罢工。在美国作家协会（WGA）结束了长达五个月的停工后，工会上周恢复了与制片厂的谈判。

双方对于演员希望从流媒体服务上的节目和电影的成功中受益的愿望存在分歧，例如演员在数十年的广播电视和重播中获得的剩余收益。 SAG-AFTRA 最初要求演员获得一部分流媒体收入，但后来将提议改为按订阅者发放奖金。

Netflix 联席首席执行官特德·萨兰多斯 (Ted Sarandos) 与其他媒体首席执行官一起参加了谈判，他表示 SAG-AFTRA 已于周三晚上首次提出按订阅者“征税”。

萨兰多斯在周四的彭博屏幕时间会议上表示：“我们只是觉得这是一座太过遥远的桥梁。”

代表 Netflix 和其他电影公司进行谈判的电影电视制片人联盟 (AMPTP) 表示，这笔奖金每年将花费 8 亿美元，在财务上“难以维持”。

SAG-AFTRA 反驳称，电影公司夸大了其提案的成本。谈判代表邓肯·克拉布特里-爱尔兰 (Duncan Crabtree-Ireland) 表示，成本约为 5 亿美元，工会认为其提供的让步更接近制片厂的要求。

克拉布特里-爱尔兰表示，“我真的希望这可能只是谈判中的一些小插曲”。 “我真的希望首席执行官团队能够保持冷静的头脑，并尽快与他们讨价还价。”

演员米歇尔·博伊德表示，她对达成协议仍持乐观态度，并受到周四参加纠察的人群的鼓舞。

“今天的投票率非常高，我认为向工作室展示我们不会离开，也不会退出，这真的很好，”她说。

双方还就人工智能在屏幕上的使用展开争论。演员们担心他们会被数字复制品取代。制片厂表示，他们提供了保证，未经同意和补偿，不会这样做。

“我们只是想要保护，这样他们就不能永远使用我们的脸，并继续永远从我的脸上赚钱，而不必再付钱给我，”演员大卫斯坦布拉说。

周四，史蒂夫·斯卡利斯(Steve Scalise)表示，他已获得共和党提名，成为下一任美国众议院议长，但未达到众议院选举所需的217票，因此已退出竞选。

他告诉记者：“我刚刚与我的同事们透露，我将撤回我作为议长指定候选人的名字。”

“如果你看看过去几周的情况，如果你看看我们的会议在哪里，仍然有工作要做……仍然有一些人有自己的议程。”

美国众议院共和党人周四进行了数小时的闭门会谈，但未能解决阻碍他们任命斯卡利斯为众议院议长的分歧，众议院已连续九天无人领导。

众议院共和党二号人物斯卡利斯已获得党内提名，接替被驱逐的议长凯文·麦卡锡。

共和党以 221 比 212 的微弱优势控制众议院，因此不能承受超过 4 人的叛逃。

距离大选还有两个多月的时间，刚果总统菲利克斯·齐塞克迪周四表示，将放宽受冲突影响的东部省份的军事统治条件，部分原因是为了鼓励参与投票。

尽管民间社会团体和反对派向他施压，但他还是没有取消北基伍省和伊图里省的戒严状态，他们表示，自 2021 年 4 月实施戒严状态以来，在遏制破坏东部稳定的许多民兵方面收效甚微。

总统在深夜向全国发表的电视讲话中表示，在受影响省份逐步放宽某些规定的情况下，将取消宵禁并允许和平示威。

他说：“这一点更加重要，因为参与选举进程的各个参与者都有权不受阻碍地充分参与。”

在他竞选连任之际，他的政府不得不否认人权组织和国际盟友关于镇压言论自由和政治异见的指控。

去年，联合国专家和国际特赦组织表示，自实施戒严状态以来，安全局势已经恶化。国际特赦组织呼吁政府终止这项政策，称该政策还导致人权状况恶化，包括骚扰记者和杀害活动人士。

尽管有刚果军队和联合国维和人员驻扎，但自 2003 年一场重大地区战争结束以来，平民仍经常面临来自北基伍和伊图里地区活跃的数十名民兵的袭击。

联合国驻刚果最高代表 9 月表示，不安全局势已导致约 600 万人流离失所。

周四，美国大使馆表示对北基伍省暴力事件增加感到担忧。 “刚果民主共和国东部的危机需要政治解决方案，而不是军事解决方案，”它在一份声明中表示。

人权观察周四指责以色列在加沙和黎巴嫩的军事行动中使用白磷弹药，称使用此类武器使平民面临严重和长期伤害的风险。

当被要求对这些指控发表评论时，以色列军方表示，“目前不知道加沙地带使用了含有白磷的武器”。它没有对人权监督机构关于在黎巴嫩使用这些设备的指控发表评论。

以色列一直在轰炸加沙，以报复哈马斯在以色列南部城镇的暴行，该事件本周造成至少 1,300 人死亡。至少 1,500 名巴勒斯坦人被杀害。以色列还与黎巴嫩真主党组织针锋相对。

人权观察表示，它核实了10月10日在黎巴嫩和10月11日在加沙拍摄的视频，显示“加沙城港口和以色列-黎巴嫩边境沿线的两个农村地区上空多次发射白磷弹”。

它提供了社交媒体上发布的两段视频的链接，称这些视频显示“正在使用 155 毫米白磷炮弹，显然是作为烟幕弹、标记或信号”。据称，这两幅作品都展示了以色列和黎巴嫩边境附近的场景。

该组织没有提供显示其据称在加沙使用的视频链接。巴勒斯坦电视频道最近几天播放的视频显示，加沙上空弥漫着细细的白烟，他们说这是由此类弹药造成的。

路透社无法独立核实该权利组织的账户。

以色列军方于 2013 年表示，将逐步淘汰 2008 年至 2009 年加沙攻势中使用的白磷烟幕弹药，该行动引起了多个权利组织的战争罪指控。

军方当时没有透露是否也会审查武器化白磷的使用，这种武器的目的是焚烧敌方阵地。

白磷弹药可以合法地在战场上使用，以制造烟幕、产生照明、标记目标或燃烧掩体和建筑物。

由于其用途合法，国际公约并未禁止白磷作为化学武器，但它会造成严重烧伤并引发火灾。

根据《禁止使用某些常规武器公约》第三号议定书，白磷被视为燃烧武器。该议定书禁止对平民中的军事目标使用燃烧武器，但以色列尚未签署该议定书，也不受其约束。

根据路透社分享的一张屏幕截图，当以色列孩子们通过 Zoom 听老师讲课时，屏幕上出现了一名穿着迷彩服的持枪男子的图像。在另一个案例中，一段视频显示以色列中部城市霍隆的一个广告牌上显示火箭和燃烧的以色列国旗的图像。

志愿者表示，在加沙战争引发的黑客活动激增之际，以色列信息安全专业人士正在联合起来，为以色列公司提供免费的网络安全服务。

路透社无法独立核实学校事件。该截图由网络安全公司 Sepio 首席执行官 Yossi Appleboum 提供。阿普尔博姆说，他通过与孩子们的家人直接联系的人收到了屏幕截图。

Zoom 没有立即回复寻求置评的消息。

被黑广告牌的视频首先于周四上午发布到 Telegram 消息服务上。总部位于以色列的网络安全公司 Check Point (CHKP.O)表示，该广告牌是至少两块此类公共显示屏之一，遭到“亲哈马斯和反以色列内容”的黑客攻击。路透社证实该视频的位置为霍隆。

与整个国家一样，以色列的科技产业也在不断变化，许多专业人士被征召入伍。这种转变为恶作剧留下了新的机会。

一群声称支持巴勒斯坦人民的黑客活动分子试图进行一系列入侵和破坏活动。网站被关闭，黑客偶尔会窃取被盗数据，但迄今为止造成的损失并不大。

以色列 IT 专家 Ohad Zaidenberg 正在带领一群志愿者帮助受到积极攻击的以色列公司。

“以色列网络社区规模庞大，而且动员既有效又感人，”他说。

以色列网络安全公司 Profero 首席执行官奥姆里·塞格夫·莫亚尔 (Omri Segev Moyal) 表示，志愿者的组织者正在与成员对哈马斯采取私刑行动划清界限。

莫亚尔运营着一个深受以色列网络安全专业人士欢迎的 Facebook 群组，他表示，他已经删除了几条呼吁针对巴勒斯坦组织采取数字行动的帖子。他说他可以理解这种冲动——“人们很生气”——但他相信私刑行动会适得其反。

莫亚尔表示，其中一名失踪者的家人已联系 Profero，要求侵入受害者的 iCloud 和手机以找到他们。

“我们拒绝了，”他说。 “我们认为这实际上会对受害者造成伤害。”

周四，科罗拉多州的一个陪审团裁定，警官兰迪·罗德玛 (Randy Roedema) 在 2019 年杀害年轻黑人伊利亚·麦克莱恩 (Elijah McClain) 时犯有过失杀人罪。

奥罗拉警官兰迪·罗德玛（Randy Roedema）和杰森·罗森布拉特（Jason Rosenblatt）在麦克莱恩之死的三项审判中的第一项受审。总之，三名警察和两名护理人员因麦克莱恩的死亡而受到指控。

检察官在整个审判过程中辩称，警察在阻止麦克莱恩时对他进行了不必要的残酷对待，并向护理人员提供了虚假信息，导致医务人员服用大剂量的氯胺酮。

辩护律师在审判期间辩称，是氯胺酮杀死了麦克莱恩，护理人员负有全部责任。

2022 年 9 月修订后的尸检报告得出结论，麦克莱恩死于“强行约束后服用氯胺酮的并发症”。

2019 年 8 月 24 日，一名旁观者拨打 911 报告称，麦克莱恩在丹佛郊区奥罗拉的一家便利店步行回家时行为可疑。安全视频显示，在一个温暖的夜晚，麦克莱恩穿着冬衣，戴着口罩，用耳塞听音乐，边走边轻轻跳舞。

根据检察官显示的随身摄像机镜头，三名奥罗拉警察赶到并在与麦克莱恩对峙九秒后抓住了他。一场斗争随之而来。视频中没有显示麦克莱恩抓枪，但可以听到一名警官大喊麦克莱恩试图夺取另一名警官的武器。检察官称麦克莱恩没有抢枪。

警察对麦克莱恩实施“颈动脉”窒息至少两次，并持续 15 分钟，直到医护人员到来。

这一事件最初没有引起多少关注，但在 2020 年 5 月黑人乔治·弗洛伊德 (George Floyd) 被明尼阿波利斯警方杀害后，该案引起了更多关注。弗洛伊德之死引发了国际社会的愤怒，并引发了针对种族不公正和警察暴行的抗议活动。

针对两名警官的首次审判于 9 月 20 日开庭。针对第三名警官的过失杀人案预计将于周五开庭。预计两名护理人员将在下个月接受审判。

朝鲜官方媒体周五谴责美国航母抵达韩国，称其为军事挑衅，可能带来“不可挽回的灾难性局面”。

核动力航空母舰罗纳德·里根号及其打击群周四抵达韩国釜山港，开始为期五天的联合演习访问，以向朝鲜展示武力。

朝鲜官方通讯社朝中社表示，这架航空母舰的访问表明，美国对其国家进行核攻击的计划已达到“最严重的阶段”，这意味着“核战争即将爆发”。

朝中社在评论中表示：“这是一次毫不掩饰的军事挑衅，将局势推向不可挽回的灾难性境地。”

美国和韩国军队今年一直在举行一系列强化的军事演习，其中包括美国航母、 潜艇和尖端轰炸机，以更好地应对朝鲜不断变化的核威胁和导弹威胁。朝鲜称这次演习是入侵的预演。

声明称，如果核攻击迫在眉睫，平壤将采取其核学说中规定的“必要行动”，并承诺“彻底威慑和击退美国及其傀儡引发核战争的疯狂举动”。

朝中社称，我们“最有力、最迅速的第一次打击将针对美国用来迷惑其追随者以及朝鲜半岛及其周边地区邪恶基地的‘延伸威慑’手段。”

伊朗外交部长侯赛因·阿米拉卜杜拉希安周四表示，针对巴勒斯坦人的持续犯罪将得到“轴心其他国家”的回应，以色列将对后果负责。

以色列一直在袭击加沙，以报复哈马斯本周在以色列发动的暴行，该暴行已造成至少 1,300 人死亡，这是以色列历史上对平民最致命的袭击。超过 1,500 名巴勒斯坦人被杀害。

Australians will be asked to vote in a referendum on Oct. 14 to constitutionally recognise its Indigenous people through the establishment of a representative body that can provide non-binding advice to the parliament.

Here's what you need to know about Australia's Voice to Parliament campaign:

WHO ARE AUSTRALIA'S INDIGENOUS PEOPLE?

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are the Indigenous people of Australia.

They represent about 3.8% of its population.超过 800,000 名原住民及其祖先在这片土地上居住了至少 60,000 年。 They comprise several hundred groups that have their own histories, traditions and languages.

WHAT ARE THE ISSUES?

Australia's Indigenous population plummeted after British colonisation began in 1788 as they were dispossessed of their land, exposed to new diseases, forced to work in slave-like conditions, and killed by colonisers.

The marginalisation of Australia's First Nations people has continued until recent years.

Aboriginal people track below national averages on most socio-economic measures and suffer disproportionately high rates of suicide, domestic violence and imprisonment. Their life expectancy is about eight years lower than non-Indigenous people.

One in three Indigenous children were forcibly removed from their families over 1910 to the 1970s in a bid to assimilate them into white society. The government apologised for the so-called 'Stolen Generation' in 2008.

ARE OTHER FORMER BRITISH COLONIES BETTER?

First Nations people in other former British colonies continue to face marginalisation, but some countries have done better in ensuring their rights.

Canada recognises the rights of its Indigenous people under the Constitution Act 1982.

New Zealand's 1840 Treaty of Waitangi promises to protect Maori culture. The country also created Maori seats in parliament, allowing the Indigenous population to choose to vote for candidates for these seats or participate in the general election.

Te reo Maori has been recognised as an official language and is used in schools, universities and public offices.

HOW DID THE VOICE REFERENDUM COME ABOUT?

Indigenous people began to be included in Australia's census figures after a referendum to amend the constitution in 1967, more than 60 years after it was established as a nation in 1901.

In 2017, about 250 First Nations representatives gathered at the sacred monolith landmark of Uluru in central Australia and produced the Uluru Statement from the Heart, which calls for a First Nations Voice enshrined in the Constitution.

The conservative government at the time rejected the call.

In 2022, Labor's Anthony Albanese became prime minister and said Australians would have their say in a referendum to include an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.

WHO IS FOR AND AGAINST THE VOICE?

The latest opinion polls this month showed more Australians are planning to vote no in the referendum than yes.

The referendum is one of Albanese's key issues and he has staked much of his political capital on it.

Albanese's Labor Party, the left-wing Greens party, some independent lawmakers, several welfare groups, national religious and ethno-religious groups all support the referendum.

But there are those who oppose it on both sides of the political divide.

Independent Indigenous senator Lidia Thorpe quit the Green party over concerns about the Voice proposal. She wants a treaty between the government and Indigenous people first, similar to what exists in New Zealand and Canada.

The conservative Liberal Party and the rural-based National Party are against the proposal and are asking Australians to vote "No" in the referendum. The Liberals and the Nationals have a long-standing coalition agreement.

A "No" campaign, or "Recognise a Better Way" campaign, has proposed to set up an all-party parliamentary committee to focus on the rights of native title holders instead of establishing a Voice to Parliament through a referendum.

Reporting by Praveen Menon in Sydney; Editing by Alasdair Pal and Stephen Coates ; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 20:06:57 GMT 6G4PH2FXEBI5VCZV5XGIY462SI https://www.reuters.com/world/what-is-australias-indigenous-voice-parliament-referendum-2023-10-12/Praveen Menon AUTRALIA INDIGENOUS/REFERENDUM (EXPLAINER) Analysis: Indigenous reconciliation at stake as Australia votes on the Voice

Phone lines at 13Yarn, a national Indigenous helpline in Australia, are ringing off the hook.

National Program Manager Marjorie Anderson's team is receiving three times more calls each week from distressed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people, as the country prepares to vote on a landmark referendum on Saturday to recognise Indigenous people in the constitution.

"Aboriginal people aren't feeling safe," Anderson, told Reuters in an interview. "When the debate gets ugly we tend to get more calls as Aboriginal people are feeling overwhelmed. They have told me they've gone off social media because it's really toxic."

Australians will vote 'Yes' or 'No' to a single line question, asking whether they agree to alter the 122-year old constitution to recognise the First Peoples. It will also create a body, called the Voice to Parliament, that can advise the government on matters affecting the Indigenous community.

Supporters believe the change will unite Australia and usher in a new era with its Indigenous people, who continue to be the most marginalised people in Australia. But polling trends indicate the 'No' vote is likely to succeed, which experts and human rights organisations fear could push back reconciliation efforts by years.

Conservatives argue the proposal divides Australia by race and gives special rights for Aboriginal people in Australia's founding document.

Misinformation across social media has also sparked fear that the Voice - a purely advisory body - will be a third chamber of parliament, resulting in more federal aid to Aboriginal people, and land disputes between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people.

As the debate echoes across the nation, Aboriginal leaders, journalists, sports personalities and others have become targets of hate speech, with many quitting public discourse.

Nathan Allen, an Aboriginal lawyer at law firm Gilbert + Tobin in Sydney, said harmful rhetoric using racist tropes had gained traction across social media.

"We are talking about business owners, board members, lawyers and chartered accountants with extremely large reach and influence that have these racist and false narrative views, and they are spreading it with all of their energy," Allen said.

'NOT CHARITY'

The Uluru Statement from the Heart, a 2017 document that proposed the Voice to Parliament and set out a roadmap for Indigenous reconciliation with wider Australia, has called for the Voice to be followed with a treaty and a truth-telling process.

"The proposed constitutional amendment is not a charity, rather an obligation flowing from international human rights law," Surya Deva, the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the Right to Development told Reuters in an interview.

In a letter to Australian authorities sent on Oct. 3, and not made public yet, the UN urged that the Voice be treated as only a first step towards the full implementation of the Uluru Statement and the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP), Deva said.

The letter would be made public on Dec. 2 after giving time for Australia to respond.

"The referendum has created unfortunate social divisions in Australia and it might take time to heal these divisions. However, we can see a positive even in this negativity: the Voice has exposed the hidden discriminatory attitude towards the Indigenous Peoples," Deva said.

Indigenous Australians, who make up 3.8% of the population, have continued to endure discrimination long after Australia became a nation in 1901. Some Indigenous and non-Indigenous leaders have asked for the referendum to be called off entirely, and the latest poll shows support for the Voice even from Indigenous voters is dropping. Most analysts expect the 'No' vote to prevail.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, a 'Yes' supporter, said he remained hopeful Australians would vote in favour of the proposal, but added he would not legislate the Voice if it was rejected.

Ian Hamm an Aboriginal man who chairs the First Nations Foundation, an Aboriginal rights organisation, said he felt his community's voice was at risk of being silenced.

The International Criminal Court has jurisdiction over potential war crimes carried out by Hamas militants in Israel and Israelis in the Gaza Strip, even though Israel is not a member state, the ICC's top prosecutor told Reuters on Thursday.

The occupied Palestinian territories including the Gaza Strip fall under the jurisdiction of the ICC, meaning the court has the authority to prosecute Hamas, the Palestinian militant group that rules Gaza.

"If there is evidence that Palestinians, whether they're Hamas or Al Quds Brigades or the armed wing of Hamas or any other person or any other national of any other state party, has committed crimes. Yes, we have jurisdiction wherever they're committed, including on the territory of Israel," ICC prosecutor Karim Khan said in an interview.

In his first comments since Hamas launched brutal attacks on Israel on Saturday and Israel responded with devastating bombings of the Gaza Strip, he said the images are "heartbreaking".

"It's horrendous what's going on, what we're seeing on our television screens. There has to be a legal process to determine criminal responsibility," he said.

"One doesn't need to be the prosecutor of the ICC. Any human being's heart must be chilled and frozen and heartbroken at seeing the pictures that are coming out of Israel and Palestine these last few days," he said.

A court of last resort, the ICC prosecutes individuals for alleged criminal conduct when its 123 member states are unwilling or unable to prosecute themselves.

世界上许多大国都不是成员国，包括中国、美国、俄罗斯、印度和埃及。 Even if the ICC were to issue warrants in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the court has no police force and would rely on member states to make arrests.

The court has had an ongoing investigation in the occupied Palestinian territories into possible war crimes and crimes against humanity there since 2021. But Israel doesn't recognise the court.

When the 2021 probe was announced, Khan's predecessor said the ICC was examining allegations of war crimes committed during 2014 hostilities in Gaza by Israeli forces, Hamas and other Palestinian armed groups. The current violence also falls under its mandate, Khan said.

Citing his own Muslim faith, Khan appealed to all sides to follow religious teachings, calling for the protection of the innocent, as well as abiding by accepted international norms for the conduct of war.

"One cannot deliberately target civilians or civilian objects. One can't rape or kill, or mutilate or dismember," he said. "Wilful killing, hostage taking are grave breaches of the Geneva Convention and one has to comply with the law."

Asked if he had a message for the warring parties in Israel and the Palestinian territories, Khan called for reflection and calm.

"This is what the moment needs, cool leadership, humanity and the realisation that the law will judge all of us," he said.

Steve Scalise , the Republican nominee to lead the US House of Representatives, faced a test on Thursday of whether he could gain enough support from his splintered party conference to be elected speaker on the chamber floor.

A day after he bested House Judiciary Chairman Jim Jordan for the nomination in a secret party ballot, the Louisiana Republican had not yet proven whether he could muster the 217 Republican votes needed to overcome Democratic opposition and be elected to the role second in line to the presidency, after the vice president.

"When we go to the floor, there'll be at least a relatively high expectation on the part of Steve Scalise and his team that he's got the votes," said Representative John Duarte, a Scalise supporter.

Republican leaders initially scheduled a House meeting for Wednesday afternoon, should Scalise, now the No. 2 House Republican, quickly come up with the votes for election. But no vote was held.

The inability of the House to act on legislation without a speaker added a sense of urgency, as Republicans faced pressure to act in support of Israel's war against Palestinian militants of Hamas and restart government funding legislation while Congress neared a new shutdown deadline on Nov. 17.

Jordan planned to vote for Scalise and encouraged his fellow Republicans to do the same, according to a source who spoke on condition of anonymity.

But a mood of uncertainly hung over the House more than a week after eight Republicans ousted former Speaker Kevin McCarthy from the job with the help of Democrats, with some lawmakers still publicly backing Jordan and others vowing to vote for McCarthy.

While McCarthy was the first speaker to be removed in a formal vote, the last two Republicans to hold the job wound up leaving under pressure from party hardliners.

"Clearly, this does not look good for the House or for the country," Representative Dusty Johnson, a Republican, told reporters. "We have incredibly tight margins, and frankly, some members who have a hard time getting to 'yes' on almost anything."

MEMORIES OF JANUARY

Republicans are determined to avoid a recurrence of the embarrassing public spectacle that occurred in January, when hardline conservatives forced McCarthy to endure 15 floor votes over four days before winning the gavel.

But that concern appeared to do little to drive unity behind closed doors, with more than a dozen lawmakers either undecided or opposed to Scalise.

Asked how long it could take to fill the speaker vacancy, Representative Richard Hudson, who chairs the House Republican campaign arm, told reporters: "No idea.".

Scalise, 58, gained near legendary status within Republican circles by surviving a severe gunshot wound after a gunman opened fire during practice for a charity baseball game in 2017. He also commands widespread respect as a veteran legislator, who has spent years in party leadership positions.

But Scalise also faces new health concerns as he undergoes treatment for multiple myeloma, a form of blood cancer, which some Jordan supporters cited as a reason not to vote for him.

"I like Steve Scalise, and I like him so much that I want to see him defeat cancer more than sacrifice his health in the most difficult position in Congress," Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, who backs Jordan, said on the social platform "X".

Jordan was endorsed by former President Donald Trump and appeared to be the favorite of populist minded hardliners.

Before his nomination, Scalise and his allies worked to defeat a closed-door effort to require a candidate to win 217 Republican votes to become the nominee. His success at defeating the move made some Jordan supporters unhappy.

拜登派遣其高级外交官安东尼·布林肯前往中东，以表明华盛顿对以色列的持久支持，寻求确保释放包括美国人在内的俘虏，并防止爆发更广泛的战争。

拜登在华盛顿举行的犹太社区领袖圆桌会议上表示，他在以色列附近部署军舰和飞机应被视为向伊朗发出的信号，伊朗支持伊斯兰组织哈马斯和黎巴嫩真主党。

“我们向伊朗人明确表示：要小心，”拜登说。

美国消息人士周三表示，伊朗可能知道哈马斯武装分子正在计划“针对以色列的行动”，但美国最初的情报报告显示，一些伊朗领导人对该组织从加沙发起的前所未有的袭击感到惊讶。

布林肯预计将于周四抵达以色列，还将访问约旦。他原本没有计划访问以色列占领的约旦河西岸，他通常在那里会见巴勒斯坦权力机构主席马哈茂德·阿巴斯。

以色列国防部长称哈马斯“将不复存在”

哈马斯附属媒体周三称，以色列对加沙南部汗尤尼斯的房屋进行空袭，造成七人死亡。

加沙卫生部表示，以色列战斗机的报复性轰炸已造成 1,100 人死亡、5,000 多人受伤。哈马斯官员称，约 535 栋住宅楼被毁，导致约 25 万人无家可归。

大多数流离失所者都住在联合国指定的避难所里，其他人则挤在破烂的街道上。

以色列在加沙附近部署了坦克和装甲车编队，可能为对哈马斯统治的沿海飞地发动地面进攻做准备。

在占领加沙 38 年后，以色列于 2005 年从加沙撤出了犹太定居者和以色列军队。自哈马斯 2007 年在该飞地夺取政权以来，以色列的封锁创造了巴勒斯坦人认为无法容忍的条件。

以色列国防部长约阿夫·加兰特周三表示，“我们将从地球上消灭这个名为哈马斯、伊斯兰国-加沙的组织”，他将哈马斯比作伊斯兰国组织。 “它将不复存在。”

拜登表示，他周三再次与以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡通话，这是他们最近几天的第四次通话，并告诉他以色列在对哈马斯的反应中应该遵循战争规则。

华盛顿表示，正在与以色列和埃及讨论食品供应短缺的加沙平民的安全通行问题。

当被问及华盛顿是否主张以色列在反应中保持克制时，布林肯在离开前表示，以色列尊重国际法并努力避免平民伤亡。

布林肯说：“我们知道以色列将采取一切可能的预防措施，就像我们一样，这也是我们与从事最令人发指活动的哈马斯和恐怖组织的区别。”

“我们都是以色列的士兵”

以色列领导人周三组建了联合政府，承诺将激烈的政治分歧放在一边，集中精力打击哈马斯。

中间派反对派领导人、前国防部长本尼·甘茨在组建完全专注于冲突的战时内阁后，与内塔尼亚胡和国防部长加兰特一起在以色列电视台现场发表讲话。

甘茨说：“我们的伙伴关系不是政治性的，而是共同的命运。” “此时我们都是以色列的士兵。”

内塔尼亚胡表示，以色列人民及其领导人团结一致。他说：“我们已经搁置了所有分歧，因为我们国家的命运岌岌可危。”

甘茨领导的民族团结党强烈反对内塔尼亚胡右翼联盟提出的司法改革，并表示在战斗继续期间不会推行任何不相关的政策或法律。

以色列对加沙进行了“全面围困”，以阻止粮食和燃料到达该地区 230 万人口，其中许多人贫困且依赖援助。哈马斯媒体周三称，唯一的发电站停止工作后停电。

由于巴勒斯坦救援人员不堪重负，其他人在拥挤的沿海地带在废墟中寻找尸体。

“当房子倒塌压在我身上时，我正在这里睡觉，”一名男子哭着说，他和其他人在一座被导弹击中的建筑物的楼梯上用手电筒寻找被困人员。
